CHAP. I.

jfn AS to empower the Lord Lieutenant, or other Chief Govtr* nor or Governors of Ireland, to apprehend and detain such Persons as he or they shallfufped for conspiring against His Majesty's Person and Government.

XXT WHEREAS a traiterous and deteilable conspiracy has* been formed for subverting the existing laws and 1797. conditution 5 therefore for the better preservation of his Majesty's sacred person, and for securing the peace, the laws, and liberties of this kingdom 5 be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons In this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That every person or person that is, are, or Persons in shall be in prison within the kingdom of Ireland, at or upon prison for high the day upon which this act shall receive his Majesty's royal tr<»fc>n, may bt assent, or after bj warrant of his Majesty's most honourable "

Not to extend to members of cither house of parliament.

may be detained in safe custody without bail or mainprize, until the first day of August, one thousand seven hundred and mnety-seven, and until the end of the then next session of parliament; and that no judge or justice of the peace shall bail or try any such person or persons so committed, without order from his said Majesty's privy council, signed by fix of said privy council, until the said first day of August, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, and the end of the then next session of parliament, any law or Statute to the contrary notwithstanding.

II. Provided always, and be it enacted, That nothing in this act, shall be construed to extend to invalidate the ancient rights and privileges of parliament, or to the imprif-onment or detaining of any member of cithet house of parliament during the fitting of such parliament, until the matter of which he (lands suspected be first communicated to the house of which he is a member, and the consent of the said house obtained for his commitment or detaining.

CHAP. II.

n An Act for encouraging and discipTining such Corps of Men as

shall voluntarily enroll themselves under Officers to be commis-Jioned by his Majesty, for the Defence of this Kingdom during the present War.

WHEREAS further exertions are now become necessary for the defence of this kingdom, and for the preservation and security of the dives and properties of his Majesty's subjects therein: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this pre-Perforsen- sent parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, rolled under That if any of his Majesty's loyal subjects in this kingdom, rfficers commis- shall have voluntarily associated and tnrolled themselves, or MajestyJduring ^all hereafter voluntarily associate and enroll themselves in the war' for the troops or companies during the continuance of the present purposes herein, war, under officers having commissions from his Majesty, or from the chief governor or governors of this kingdom, duly authorized thereto by his Majesty, for the protection of property, and preservation of the peace within the barony, city, or town wherein the place of first assembling shall be appointed in such commission, and within every barony, city, or town immediately adjoining thereto, every serjeant, trumpeter, drummer, and private therein, shall be intitled'to receive inch clothing, arms, and accoutrements, or allowances

The thirty seventh Year of George III., 3

ances in lieu thereof, and also such pay, in such manner A.D. and at such rate, as his Majesty, or the chief governor or 1797* governors of this kingdom shall appoint, for every day, not Chap. a. exceeding two days in each week that he shall actually assemble and attend by order of his commanding officer for the purpose of being disciplined, and exercised.

II. And be it further enacted, That one serjeant, and one Dally pay to

trumpeter or drummer in ev$ry such troop or company, serjeant shall be entitled to receive permanent or daily pay, to be or

appointed in like manner, during the continuance of such

troop or company.

III. And be it further enacted, That neither such enrol- Such person* ment nor the receiving of pay, or allowances as aforesaid, p°ovisionsVf° shall subject any perkm so enrolled, or receiving pay, to mutiny s&. military discipline or duty, or to the provisions of any act

for punishing mutiny and desertion.

IV. And be it further enacted, That if the officer commanding any such troop or company as aforesaid, shall dif- Up arms, °&tTe

charge from such troop or company any person; or if any after being dif-

person shall withdraw from such troop or company, who' charged or with*

shall have been enrolled as aforesaid, and if such person shall dra^m, forfeit

refuse or neglect, on being required by such commanding officer to deliver up any arms, accoutrements, or clothing*

which shall have been entrusted to his custody, every person

so refusing or neglecting, shall, on being convicted thereof

before any justice of the peace of the county* within which such trbop or company shall have been formed, forfeit and

pay the sum of ten pounds, to be levied by distress and

sale of the offender's.goods and chattels, by warrant under

the hand and seal of such justice, rendering the overplus (if

any) on demand, after deducting the charges of such dif-

tress and sale, to the person whose goods and chattels shall have been so distrained and fold; and for want of such

sufficient distress, such justice is hereby required to-commit

such offender to the common gaol of the county, city, or

VII. CHAP. XVIII.

An Act to prevent Exactions upon the Sale of Salt*

WHEREAS it is necessary for the benefit of the poor, to prevent exactions upon the sale of salt in this kingdom, and to have the rates and prices thereof ascertained; be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the adviee and consent oT the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That the lord mayor and court I of

The thirty-seventh Year of George III.

of ldermen of the city of Dublin, shall and may, and are hereby required, in the court of aldermen, within the city* of Dublin, on or before the first day of May, in the year of our lord, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, set, ascertain, and publish in writing, and in the publick news-jLoro jvia or PaP€r8> certain reasonable rates and prices upon all-salt of IusticeTYc.r, for every kind and denomination, to be sold or exposed to sale trice of after the said first day of May, in the city of Dublin, or

within the liberties or precincts thereof; and that the justices of peace for the several counties within the kingdom of Ireland, shall and may (and are hereby required on or before the first day of June, in the year of our lord, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, at the respective quarter sessions, or at the quarter sessions to be next held after the passing of thisa&, ) let, ascertain, and duly publish in writing, in the manner and place most convenient for the publick, certain reasonable rates and prices upon all salt to be sold, or exposed to falc after the said first day of June, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, or after the date of the said quarter fcflions within the said counties; and that the lord mayor of Dublin, and the court of aldermen, in th? court of al-deimen, and that the said justices of the peace of the respective counties, at the respective quarter-sessions thereafter held, shall and may, and are hereby requiied, from time to time, if necessary, by writing duly made and published as ' aforesaid, alter and correct the rates and prices of all salt to

be sold, or exposed to falc, in the said respective places; which rates and prices which shall be so set and ascertained, or altertd and corrected, are hereby enacted ?nd required to be obferred and received by all and every person or persons felling or exposing to sale any salt within the kingdom of Ireland; and if any person or persons shall fell any salt at any higher price or rate, or refute to fell any salt at the prices and rates fa fixed as aforesaid, such person or persons so offending, shall for every such offence, forfeit and pay the sum of ten pounds sterling, to be levied out of the goods and chat-> tels of such offender or offenders, by distress and sale thereof* by warrant under the hand and seal of the lord mayor of the city of Dublin, or of any justice or justices of the peace for the place or places wherein such offence shall be committed, or distress shall be to be made; and in default of suficient distress for the same, it shall and may be lawful by warrant under the hand and seal from the lord mayor of the city of Dublin, or fiom any justice of the peace as aforesaid, to imprison the said offender or offenders, until such offender or offenders shall pay the said sum of ten pounds sterling, one moiety of which sum of ten pounds is hereby ena&ea to be paid to the use of the poor in the parish in which the said

XVII. Provided also, and be it enacted, That if any person so drawn by ballot, and failing to appear, shall afterwards voluntarily appear, at a time when the militia is complete, he shall be immediately enrolled, and shall be bound in the sum of twenty pounds, and shall find a sufficient surety, to be bound in the sum of ten pounds, for his appearance, and joining the militia whenever there shall be a vacancy, or he shall be required by the commanding officer or clerk of the sub-division to join, and his time of service shall commence from the day of his joining; and if he shall so fail to bind himself, or to find such surety, he shall be committed by any magistrate, governor, or deputy governor to the common gaol or the county, there to remain until he shall so bind himself, and find such surety, or until he shall be sent to the regiment or battalion to serve therein.

XVIII. And be it further enacted, That if any general, or sub-divisional meeting shall be omitted to be held, pursuant to the provisions of this act, a meeting may, in lieu thereof, be held at such time or place as shall be appointed for the purpose, by notice in writing, signed by any governor, or two deputy governors, and all such meetings, and all meetings of governors, or deputy governors may adjourn as they find expedient, for the execution of this act, and shall exercise the like powers; and all acts done thereat, shall be deemed as valid to all intents and purposes, as if done at meetings held in manner, and at the times heretofore respectively enabled; and no aft, matter or thing, done at any general or sub-divjfional meetings, or at such adjournment, shall be impeached, or deemed invalid for want of form, in the manner or time of such meeting being held.

— CHAP. XXI.

An Act to amend the Game Laws.

m

WHEREAS by an act passed In the twenty-seventfi year of his present Majesty's reign, entitled, An m3 the trefervation of the game % it is enacted* That from am! after the first day of June, one thousand seven hundred and eighty-seven, evciy person who shall willfully take, kill, or destroy, or who shall sell or expose to sale, or who shall buy, or cause to be bought, any moor-game, heath-game, or grouse, between the tenth day of December and seventh day of August, or any pheasant, partridge/ quail, landrail, or wild turkey, between the tenth day of January and rtrft day of September, in any year, shall forfeit a sum not exceeding five pounds, for every such moor-game, heath-game, or grouse, pheasant, partridge, quail, land-rail, or wild turkey; and whereas the fcarehing for, taking and killing of moor-game, heath-game, or grouse, at so early a period as the time specified in the said act, has been found very prejudicial, and the taking and killing of partridges at so early a period as the first day of September, has been found very prejudicial to the farmers and husbandmen throughout the kingdom, for remedy whereof, be it enade4 by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the Part of recit- authority of the same, That from and after the passing of repealed this act, so much of the said recited act as relates to the taking, killing, destroying, felling, or exposing to sale, any moor-game, heath-game, or grouse, between the tenth day of December and seventh day of August, in any year, or any partridge between the tenth day of January and first day of September, in any year, shall be, and the same is hereby declared to be repealed

II. CHAP. XXIX.

An Act for improving and repairing the Roads leading from the City of Dublin to Ratoath and Curragha, and for altering and amending an Act passed in the Thirty fifth Year of his Amended 38 Present Majesty's Reign, entitled, An Act for making, wid+G- 3- 3X. 6o* eningy and repairing the Road leading from the City of Dub*

Iin to Rat oat by and for ere Bing Turnpikes thereon, in Aid of Barony Preferments*

WHEREAS an act of parliament passed in the

thirty-fifth year of the reign of his present Majes- Recital 35 0. J. ty, entitled, An act for makingy widening, and repairing the road leading from the city of Dublin to Ratoath y and for erecting turn pikes thereony in aid of barony preferments; and whereas several of the provisions of the said act have been found infuffi* cient for the purposes thereby intended; be it therefore enacted by the King's mo ft excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That 1 he before recited act, fate so far a3 is herein after excepted, be, and the same is hereby repealed.

III. And be it further enacted, That all sums of money in the hands of the trustees named in the said recited act, or of the treasurer by them appointed, or which were directed by the said act to be paid to the said trustees, or Which are in the hands of any ptrfun or persons, for the use of the said trustees, or to which the said trustees are in any manner entitled, by virtue of the said act, be, and the same are hereby directed to be paid over to the trustees herein named, upon such security given by them for the just expenditure thereof, as was required from the trustees named in the said recited act.

IV. And be it further enacted, That whenever any of the said trustees herein appointed by name, shall happen to die, or resign, it shall be lawful for the remaining trustees, or any seven or more of them, on the first Thursday in any month, to elect a person to be a trustee in his stead, and so as often as a vacancy shall happen by the death or resignation of any person lo chosen.

V. And be it enacted, That fev£n trustees shall be necessary to coi.stitute a meeting of the said trustees, and that the act of the majority of seven, legally convened, shall be the ad of, &iid binding upon the said trustees.

And be it further enacted, That in all cases where the said directors shall alter ttie present road by taking off any unnecessary angles, or making a new line of road, they shall cause a map of such parts of the present road, as shall in consequence thereof, b£ discontinued by them, as part of the turnpike road, for the use of travellers, to be deposited with the treasurer of the county, in which such parts shall be situate; and if the grand jury of such county shall not within eight months, from the time such map shall be so deposited, present such parts to be kept open as a public road, every such part of the old road as shall not be so presented, shall be, and is hereby declared to be vested in the said directors, for the benefit of the said road, and shall and may be set or sold by the said directors, or any three of them, and the relit or money arising therefrom, shall be applied by them towards the payment of the rents, or purchase of such grounds as they may think proper to take by yearly relit, or to purchase for any of the purposes herein before mentioned.

XXXV. Provided always, That no such presentment for keeping open any such part of the present road, shall be made by any grand jury, except upon an affidavit of two credible persons, who can read and write, setting forth that such part of the road is necessary to be kept open, as a publick road, for the convenience of travellers.

And the more effectually to prevent the clandestine importation cf tea, be it enacted, That a penalty of twelve shillings per pound for green, and nine shillings per pound for bonea tea, over and above all other penalties already inflicted by law, shall be, and are hereby laid and irt-posed on every hawker, retailer, or grocer, in whose custody tea clandestinely imported shall be found, and also on all and every other person and persons in whose custody tea imported as aforesaid shall be found, knowing the same to be smuggled, one moiety thereof to the use of his Majesty, his heirs and successors, the other moiety to the use of the seizing officer or informer.

And be it enacted, That if after the duty on anf malt shall have been paid by, or charged on any maltster, or maker of malt, or other person having malt in his or their possession, any quantity of such malt, shall by inevitable accident happen to be damaged or destroyed, it shall and may be lawful for the respective proprietors of such malt, to make such proof thereof, on the oath of one or more credible witness or witnesses, before the principal officer of excise, in the respective districts where such malt was damaged or destroyed, which oath every such officer is hereby authorized and required to administer, and upon such proof, or other proof being made to the satisfaction of the commissioners of the revenue, or any three of them, and like proof that the malt was entirely lost or destroyed, or so damaged as to be totally unfit for use, and that the duty thereof was charged or paid, as the case shall be, it shall and may be lawful for them to pay or allow to the proprietor, or proprietors of such malt, out of any money in the hands of any collector, not appropriated to any particular purpose, so much money as shall have been charged or paid for the duty of the malt To lost or destroyed, or damaged, or to vacate the charge as, to so much of the duties as shall have been charged only andot paid.

FOR the better securing of his Majesty's revenue on tobacco, and for regulating the tobacco trade, and extending the same, by allowing importers of tobacco, to lodge their tobacco in warehouses, ^and to have time for the payment of the duty thereon; be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with tht advice and consent of the h us spiritua]' and temporal, and commons in thi*3 present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That every importer of tobacco, shall and may fe-cuit a duty, after the rate of four-pence for every pound weight thereof, in manner following; that is to say, he or she shall give bond for the amount of the import duty, then payable thereon; such bond to be made payable at the end of fifteen moutlis, to commence from the date of such bond.

II. Provided always, That where tobacco shall be landed on bill of view, the importer or owner of such tobacco, flinil, within ten working days, after the landing of such tobacco* make entry thereof, and pay the duty for the same, or enter into bond for the payment thereof, in manner herein directed, and in failure thereof, every such person shall forfeit the sum of five pounds, for every hogfnead of such tobacco, which shall not be entered, and for which the duty shall not have been paid or ftcured as aforesaid, over and above the duties payable on such tobacco.

XIX. XXII. And be it enacted, That if any clerk of the peace shall grant or issue any license for the sale of beer, ale, cider, or spirituous liquors by retail, to any perfoa who shall not have produced and lodged with him a certificate, with the receipt of the collector endorsed theron, pursuant to the provisions of this act, every such clerk of the peace, shall for every such offence forfeit the furrr of one hundred pounds, to be recovered by any person who shall sue for the same, by action of debt, bill, plaint, or information in any of his Majesty's courts of record in Dublin; and if upon such action or information, a verdict shall be given, and judgment entered thereon against the defendant, such clerk of the peace shall forfeit his office, and be for ever disabled from being again appointed thereto.

XXIII. And be it enacted, That the several clerks of the peace, shall keep the several certificates, upon which licenses shall issue for the sale of beer, ale, cider, or spirituous liquors, and the recognizance entered into, according to the provisions of this act, amongst the records of the county, and shall upon demand of any one or more justice or justices of the peace produce the same for his or their in-Ipc&ion, and any two or more justices of the peace, may impose any fine, not exceeding the sum of twenty pounds, upon any such clerk of the peace, who shall omit, or ne-gle& to keep such certificates and recognizances in a regular manner, which fine shall be elheated into h; Majesty's exchequer.

XXIV. And be it enacted, That the several clerks of the peace, shall so often as they shall be thereunto required by notice signed by one or more commissioner or of of excise, transmit to the excise office in Dublin, a true and accurate lift of all licenses granted by them respectively, and the dates of such licenses, the names of the persons licensed, and the places where they shall be licensed to fell beer, ale, cider, or spirituous liquors; and if any clerk of the peace shall refuse or omit to return such lift, within ten days after such notice as aforesaid, every such clerk of the peace so offending shall forfeit the sum of twenty pounds.

An Act for the Relief and Maintenance of Insolvent Debtors detained in Prison.

WHEREAS many persons are detained prisoners in close custody for debt, by the obduracy of cruel creditors, though cotifcious such debtors are utterly unable to discharge the same, by which means such prisoners are prevented from exercising such industry, at might enable them to procure for themselvefc and families daily sustenance and support, who are therefore often destitute of the lame; be it enacted by the Kind's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, for the case, relief, and maintenance of all persons who shall at any time hereafter be prisoners under execution, or mesne process, for any debt or debts not exceeding two hundred pounds, and who shall be willing to fetisfy their respective creditors as far as they are able, that from and after the first day of June, ' one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, if any person or persons shall be charged in execution, or imprisoned under mesne process for any sum or fuma of money not exceeding in the whole the sum of two hundred pounds, on which execution, or mesne procefr, there shall at any time remain doe, as shall be made to appear by oath, a sum or sums of money not amounting above the said sum of two hundred pounds, and shall he minded to deliver up to his, her, or their creditor or creditors, who shall so charge him, her, or them, in execution, or under mesne process, all his, her, or their estate and effects, for or towards the fdtisfaction of the debt or debts wherewith he, she, or they shall so (land charged or committed, it shall and may be lawful to and for any such prisontr, before the end of the first term which shall be next after any such prisoner shall be charged in execution, or committed under mesne process, by his creditor or creditors, to exhibit a petition to any court of law from whence the process iflfued, upon which' any such prisoner was or \frere taken 3nd charged in execution, or mesne -process, as aforesaid, or to the coart into which any such prisoner shall be removed by habeas corpus, pr shall be charged iq custody, and shall remain in the prison thereof, certifying the cause or causes of his, her, or their imprisonment, and sot only setting forth in every such petition a

IX. And whereas the use of narrow-wheeled carts, cars, and drays, hath been found to be very injurious to the pavements of the city of Dublin, and.to the highways in and about the neighbourhood thereof: for remedy whereof, be it enacted, That from and after the twenty-fourth day of June, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, no dray, cart or car, drawn by one horse, to be licensed by virtue of this act, shall ply within the said city* suburbs, or liberties, or within seven miles thereof, unless the wheels thereof

WHEREAS it would tend greatly to Secure the free-dom of election, and the quiet, tranquillity and good order of cities, boroughs, and towns-corporate if a certain reasonable limitation of time, were by law established beyond which no member <*r officer of any city, borough, or town-corporate, Should be disturbed in the enjoyment or e$-ercife of hi* office or franchise: be it therefore enacted by the Sing's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and tempoial, and commons in parliament assembled, That after the first day of Easter term, in the year one thousand Seven hundred and ninety-eight, it shall and may be lawful for the defendant or defendants to any information, in the nature of a quo warranto, for the exercise of any office or franch ife, in any cky, borough, or town-corporate, whether exhibited with leave of the court, or by his Majesty's attorney-general, or other officer of the crown, on behalf of his Majesty, by virtue of any royal prerogative, or otherwise, and every of them Severally and respectively to plead that he or they had first actually taken upon themselves, or held, or executed the office of franchise, which is the subject of loch information, six years or more before the exhibiting of such information, such six years to be reckoned and computed front the day on which such defendant or defendants so pleading, shall have been actually admitted and sworn into such office or franchise; which plea shall or may be pleaded either sing-ly, or together with and besides such plea as he or they might have lawfully pleaded before the passing of this act, or such Several pleas as the court on motion shall allow; ar, d if upon the trial of such information, the issue joined apou such plea shall be found for the defendant or defendants, or any of them, he or they shall be entitled to judgment, and to such and the like cods, as he or they would by law have been entitled to, if a verdict and judgment had been given for him or them upon the merits of his or their title.

II. And be it enacted, That the rates and duties charged on auctions shall be, and are hereby declared to be a charge upon every auctionier or feller by commission, immediately from and after the closing of the bidding at every sale, by way of auction, and that the rates and duties lo charged shall be paid by every such auctionier or feller by commission, in manner and at the times herein after mentioned.

Ill Provided always, That nothing in this act contained shall restrain any auctionier from making it a condition of sale, that the said duties, or any portion thereof, shall he paid by the purchaser, over and above the price which shall have been bidden at such auction; and in such case the aue-tionier is hereby required to demand payment of the duty from such purchaser, or such portion thereof as shall be expressed in such condition and agreement; and upon the neglect or refusal of such purchaler to pay such duty, such bidding at such au£lion shall be void.

IV. Provided also, That nothing herein contained shall extend, of be construed to extend, to alter, determine, or make void any other condition or agreement whatsoever, between any buyer or feller by auction, or any other person, touching the payment of any of the said duties, so as the same do not extend to the lessening of the full sum charged thereon.

so as to turn round the axletree, and whose axletjpe shall be fixed, so as not to turn round with the wheels, the sum of one penny only* and no more, shall be demanded, or taken at any such gate, for each horse, or other beast drawing the same, if the (freaks or (hoeing of such wheels be set on with counter-funk flat-headed nails, bolts, or ferews.

III. Provided always nevertheless. That any other passenger or passengers travelling with the same cattle or carriage which hath been so charged as aforesaid, shall be liable to, and accordingly be charged the like toll, as herein before mentioned, with the same cattle or carriage, notwithstanding toll had been before paid for the same cattle or carriage by other paiTenger or passengers within the same division in the same day, it being the true intent and meaning hereof, that each and every person and persons travelling in carriages, shall contribute to, and be liable to defray the expence of repairing and keeping in repair the said turnpike-road.

IV. Provided also, That such cattle or carriage, so before charged with the payment of toll in the same division in any one day, shall not on returning with the same passenger or passengers, or without any passenger or passengers, be liable to the payment of any further or other toll, than as aforesaid.

XXXIII. And be it enacted, That If any person shall aCTault, oppefe, moled, obstruct, or hinder any officer or officers of excise, in tike due execution of this act, or of any of the powers or authorities given by this act, every such person so offending, shall, for every such offence, forfeit the sum of one hundred pounds: Provided, and it is hereby declared, That paste-board made in Ireland, wholly of paper which shall have paid the duty of excise charged thereon, shall not be charged with any further or other duty, in respect of the passing or annexing together the sheets of such paper, and its receiving thereby the denomination of pasteboard or passed paper.

And be it enacted, That any person who shall be convictedof wilfully taking afalie oath or affirmation, In any of the cases in which an oath or affirmation is required to be taken, by virtue of this act, in order to obtain any drawback or allowance by this act granted, shall be liable to the pains and penalties to which persons are liable for wilful and corrupt perjury.

XXXV. And whereas it is expedient that foreign paper Should not be imported in any less quantity than a ream; be it therefore enacted, That if any foreign piper shall be imported into this kingdom, in any less quantity than a ream, each such ream containing twenty quites, and each quire (hereof twenty-four sheets, the same shall be forfeited, and shall and may be seized by any officer or officers of the Revenue.

A.D. 1798.

An Act for granting certain Tolls, Rates] and Duties, ' to he taken at the Turnpikes, on the Roads leading over Bally-hough and Annesley Bridges, in Aid of the Barony Preferments, and in Lieu of the Tolls formerly payable at such Turnpikes, and for amending the Laws for makings widening^ and repairing the said Roads, and for making perpetual the several Acts of Parliament relating thereto.

WHEREAS the tolls, rates, and duties, payable by several acts of parliament, for making, widening, and repairing the road from Dublin to Malahide, and the other roads leading to Dublin, over Hally bough-bridge, arc not sufficient, after paying the sums required by law to be applied towards the discharge of the money borrowed in pursuance of the said acts, and the ijitered thereof, to make the said roads, and keep the same in proper repair: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That from and after the Tolls shall puffing of this act, the following tolls, rates and duties shall be paid, as be paid at any- gate, bar, or toll-house erected, or which herein.

CHAP. XLVI.

An Act for the government of the Militia of Great Britain, serving in thii Kingdom, during their continuance therein.

Regulations and provisions for British mi-litis serving in thi. kingdom, si herein.

Regulations for militia officers in courts martial, 8c c.

WHEREAS on the breaking out of the unnatural and wicked rebellion now existing in this kingdom, from an ardent zeal for the interests of his Majesty, and their country, and from an affectionate concern for their loyal fellow-subje&g of this kingdom, the officers, noji-commissioned officers and privates, of divers of his Majesty's regiments of British Militia, made a voluntary offer to his Majesty of their fen-ices to be employed in this kingdom, for the suppression of the said unnatural rebellion, and thereupon an act of parliament was passed in Great Britain, to empower his' Majesty for a time, and to an extent thereby limited, to accept the services of such parts of his militia forces of Great Britain, as may voluntarily offer themselves to be employed in Ireland: And whereas his Majesty has been graciously pleased to order a considerable body of the said British militia, who have offered their services, in aid of their loyal fellow subjects of Ireland* to be landed in this kingdom, and it is necessary to provide for their good government, and for the preservation of the rank of their officers during their continuing in this kingdom: be it enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That it shall and may be lawful to and for the lord lieutenant, or other chief governor or governors of this kingdom, to command, or to put any of the militia forces of Great Britain, who shall land io this kingdom, pursuant to the said at\ of the British parliament, under the command of such general officers, as he or they shall be pleased to appoint, and during their continuance in this kingdom, the officers, non-commissioned officers, and privates of the several regiments of the said British militia, shall be subject to all the provisions contained in an act of parliament passed in the present session of parliament in this kingdom, entitled, An act for punishing mutiny and desertion, and for the better payment of the army, and their quartersy within this Kingdom.

II. Provided always, and be it enacted, That no officer serving in his Majesty's regular forces, or in his Majesty's militia of Ireland, shall fit in any court-martial for the trial

of

t

The thirty-eighth Year of George III.

of any officer, or soldier serving irf the British militia, nor A.D. shall any officer of the British militia fit in any court-mar- 1798. tial upon the trial of any officer or soldier serving in his Majesty's regular forces, or militia of Ireland. Rank of of!U

III. And be it further enacted, That the officers of the ccr, r said British militia, whillt serving in Ireland, shall rank with the officers of his Majesty's regular forces, as they would have ranked with the officers of his Majesty's regular forces, had they remained in Great Britain, and shall rank with the officers of his Majesty's militia of Ireland, according to the dates of then* respective commissions of the same rank.

An Act to enable the Dean and Chapter of Christ Church, Dulling and other Perf oris therein named, to grant certain Grounds in the City of Dublin, to the Society of Kin % 's Inns, Dublin.

WHEREAS the ptofeflors of the law in this kingdom, were from the year one thousand five hundred and forty-two, possessed of the feite, circuit, ambit and precinct of the monastery or house of the ftiars preachers, or black friars, situate in the suburbs of the city of Dublin, with other lands, by virtue of leases for years thereof, made to them by his Majesty King Henry the eighth, and his successors, and the same were afterwards granted to them ia fee by his Majesty, King James the first, at the annual relit of twenty shillings, to the end that it Should be a perpetual residence for them, and their successors, and they continued torefide therein, and the same were known by the name of the King's Inna, until the year of our lord, one thousand seven hundred and forty-two, when the buildings became ruinous and unfit for the purposes of the society: And whereas by an act of parliament passed in the twenty-fifth year of his late Majesty, King George the second, the ground comprized in the said feite, was vested in certain trustees, who were thereby empowered to set or fell the same, or, any part of it, and to purchase other ground, or to build on an part of the said ground not fold, or demised, and they cannot now build on the said ground, the greatest part thereof being occupied by the courts of justice, and the public offices lately built thereon: and whereas the right honourable and right reverend and reverend the dean and chapter of the cathedral church of the Holy. CHAP. LV.

An Act for the King's Most Gracious, General and Free Pardon.

THE king's most excellent Majesty being always desirous to shew his royal inclination to mercy, and considering that divers of his subjects have rendered them-Telves obnoxious to the laws, and subject to the highest penalties, by being concerned in the unnatural rebellion which had broken forth in this kinfgdom, from which they can in no wife be freed, but by his Majesty's great goodness and clemency; and that some of fijs Majesty's subjects, in fiip-pressing, counterading, and putting down the said rebellion, may have done divers acts, which could not be justified by (he (bid terms of law; and being gracioudy inclined to yncourage all his loving subjects to return and continue in their due obedience to his Majesty, rather by acts of grace and mercy, than by a severe execution of justice, and desirous of quieting the minds of his subjects in general, hath, upon mature deliberation, resolved and determined to grant his general and free pardon, in a large and bountiful manlier, not doubting but that however it may be received by those who are obstinately bent on the ruin of their country, it will raise a due sense of gratitude in all who have been artfully raided into trcasonable practices against his person

CHAP. LXXIV.

An Act for indemnifying such Persons as have aSed since the First Day of November, one thousand frven hundred and ninety seven, for the Preservation of the Public Peace9 and Suppression of InsurreQions prevailing infqme Parts of tins Kingdom.

Diiforbaftces and rebellion since Nov,

1799>*c-

WHEREAS fmee the first day of November, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, several parts of this kingdom have been disturbed by treasonable in-furredion* and open rebellion, and the lives and properties of many peaceable and faithful subjects destroyed, and many of his Majesty's loyal subjects have lost their lives in said rebellion; and several officers and justices of the peace, and other persons, in order to preserve the public peace, the lives and properties of his Majesty's faithful subjects, and to suppress and put an end to such insurrections and rebellion, have apprehended several criminals suspected of being concerned in said practices of insurrection and rebellion, and without due authority, have sent other criminals, or suspected persons out of the kingdom, and have been obliged to do divers other acts not justifiable by law, but which were yet so much for the public service, and so necessnry for the suppression of such insurrection and rebellion, that the persons by whom they were transacted ought to be indemnified: be it therefore enacted by the King's most excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the lords spiritual and temporal, and commons in this present parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, That all personal actions, suits, indictments, informations, attachments, molcftations, prosecutions, and proceedings whatever, judgments and orders, if any be, against the said magistrates and persons, for, or by reason of any matter or thing, commanded, appointed or done since the first day of November, one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, in order to suppress the said insurrections and rebellion, and for the preservation of the public peace, or for the iafety of the state, shall be discharged and made void, ai.d that every person by whom any such ad, matter or thing, shall have been advised, commanded, appointed or done for the purposes aforesaid, since the first day of November, in the year one thousand seven hundred and ninety-seven, shall be freed, acquitted and indemnified, as well agaiuil the King's Majesty, his heirs and successors, as against all and 2 every i

i

The thirty-eighth Year of George III.

every other person and persons; and that if any profccu* tien, action or fuijt, hath been, or shall be commenced or prosecuted against any perfori, for any such act, matter or thing so advised, commanded, appointed or done, for the purposeq aforesaid, or any of them, he or she may plead the general issue, and give this act and the special matter ia evidence; and' if the plaintiff or plaintiffs shall become non* suit, or forbear further prosecution, or suffer difeout in nance, or if a verdict pass against such plaintiff or plaintiffs, the defendant or defendants shall recover his, her, or their double costs, fqr which he, she, or they (halt have the like remedy, as in cases in which coils by law are given tQ defendants.

II. And be it enacted, That no wine of the growth or produce of.ortugal, shall be imported into this kingdom, or into any port, haibour, haven, or creek thereof, in any bottle, jar, caAt, or other vessel, which shall contain fiity-three gallons at lealt, upon pain of forfeiting such wine, and the bottle, jar, cask or vessel, in which such wine shall be Contained.

III. And whereas several ill-disposed person$ do frequently dye, fabricate or manufacture veiy great quantities of floe leaves, liquorice leaves, and the leaves of tea that have been before used, or the leaves of other trees, shrubs or plants, in imitation of tea, and do likewise mix, colour, (lain and dye such leaver, and likewise tea, with Terra Japonica, sugar, molasses, clay, logwood and other ingredients, and do fell and vend the same as true and real tea, to the prejudice of the health of his Majesty's subjects, the diminution of the revenue, and to the ruin of the fair trader; for remedy of such frauds and abuses for the future, be it enacted, That if any person or persons shall dye, fabricate or manufacture any floe raves, liquorice leaves, or the leaves of tea that have been used, or the leaves of any other tree, (brub, or plant, mitation of tea, or shall mix, colour, (tain or dye such leaves or tea, with Terra Japonica, sugar, molasses, clay, logwood, or with any other ingredients or materials what foe ver, or shall fell and vend, or utter, offer, or expose to sale, or shall have in his, her, or their custody or possession, any such dyed, fabricated or manufactured leaves, in imitation of tea, or any such coloured, itained or dyed leaves, pr tea mixed with any of the ingredients before mentioned, or with any other ingredients whatsoever, such yjerfon or persons shall respectively, for every pound of such leaves so dyed, fabricated or manufactured in imitation of tea, and for every pound of such mixed, colouied, (tained or dyed leaves or tea, forfeit and pay the sum of ten pounds, together with all such leaves or tea, which leaves or tea arty officer or officers of his Majesty's revenue is and are hereby required jnd empowered to seize.

IV. And be it enacted, That all shrub, or other mixed spirits imported into this kingdom, shall be deemed and taken to be single spirits, or spirits perfectly made, and pay duty as such.

And in order to prevent frauds by not fending per-mita with exciseable goods, be it enacted, That all wines in casks, bottles, jars, or other frefTels, any quantity of brandy or other foreign spirits, or of tfrong waters or spirits made in this kingdom, exceeding four gallons; all tobacco or snuff above the weight of four poundsj coffee exceeding two pounds weight; malt exceeding fix flonet weight s sugar exceeding in weight fifty-six pounds; silk in whole pieees, and East India goods, other than and except fpicerias of all forts, and except tea, exceeding the weight of two pounds, and all other exciseable goods whatsoever, that shall be carrying or conveying, or carried or conveyed from any part or place within this kingdom, to any other part thereof, whether from any part of any city or town, to another part thereof, or from one town or place to another town oi place, shall be liable to be seized by any officer or officers of his Majesty's revenue, and shall be deemed and taken to be run goods and forfeited as such, unless the carrier or person conveying the same, or the person in whose possession the same shall be, shall produce a permit or let-pass, under the hand of a proper officer f the revenue, authorising the removal of such goods, if fa h person shall be required so to do by any such officer.

XII. Provided always, That if the carriage of such goods shall be prevented from being fully performed within the time limited in such permit, by any unavoidable accident, then, on notice being immediately given by the owner or carrier of such goods, to any officer of the revenue, and a rest or stay being made of such goods, at or near the place where such accident shall happen, the officer of the revenue to whom such notice shall be given, shall, without delay repair to the place where such good3 shall th<; n be, and if such officer shall find, upon view or enquiry, such goods were Hopped or delayed in their carriage by such accident, then such officer shall thereupon, by endorsement on such permit, enlarge the time for the carriage of such goods to the place of their first destination; and if any officer of the revenue, shall wilfully or negligently omit or refuse to do his duty herein, according to the directions aforesaid, such officer shall, on proof being made thereof, to the Satisfaction of the chief of of his Majesty's revenue, or any three or more of them, forfeit the ium of ten pounds.

And be it enacted, That it shall and may be lawful for any officer of his Majesty's revenue to enter, in the day-time, into any»house, out house, store-house, or other place belonging to any person or persons dealing in, storing, or having in his, her or their possession, any spirits or strong waters made in this kingdom, exceeding four gallons, and to demand a permit or let-pass, signed by. the proper officer of -excise, for such spirits as shall be found therein, and if on demand made by any such officer, such permit or let-pass, or a certificate under the hand of a proper officer, that a permit had been lodged with him, shall not be produced within a reasonable time after such demand, or proof made that a permit had been granted for the same, and was afterwards lost or mislaid, then all such spirits or strong wateis, together with the casks or vessels in which they shall be contained, shall be forfeited, and shall and may be seized by any officer of his Majesty's revenue.
